item.description: Podcast about podcasts for teaching and learning
item.author: Kristi Ajazi, Virgilio Efrain Martinez Caliva, Anton Tetov Johansson, Kunal Sharma, David Wenander
item.content:encoded:
References used in the podcast episode

  1. Nataatmadja, I. and Dyson, L.E., 2008. The role of podcasts in students’ learning. International Journal of Interactive Mobile Technologies, 2(3), pp.17-21.
  2. Drew, C., 2017. Educational podcasts: A genre analysis. E-Learning and Digital Media, 14(4), pp.201-211.

Additional reading

The word podcasting originates from the combination of iPod and broadcasting, and poddies is a term used to define listeners of podcasts. In 2004 the word podcast resulted in 24 hits according to a Google search, however by 2007 this number rose up to 124 million.

Podcasts have the benefit of allowing anytime, anywhere learning. Students can access the material when travelling, commuting, or even at home. The recordings can be played at a convenient for them time.

Podcasts are not interactive it is a one-way learning model which can be supplemented by other teaching techniques and reinforce the learning process. Early career students transition from a more on-on-one approach in high school to university where this style of teaching is not easily obtained. In those cases, podcasts can be used as supplements to aid in more study material outside of the given teaching times.

In this study, 53% of the students that used podcasts said it helped their understanding of the topics. International students that struggled with the language of instruction said it helped them understand better and also enhanced their language skills in the field.

Some students preferred text or transcripts as they simply do not enjoy audio stimulation and find it less informative which shows that they have a different learning technique.

Active listeners according to [2] are more likely to use this tool and use it as a way to engage in the subject with their preferred learning technique.

Instead of enhancing learning, these tools allow for a different approach that might help students become more engaged in the topic and supply more conversation topics between the teacher and students.

Using podcasts as a cognitive tool might help students become more engaged in a deeper learning context.

Supplying condensed summaries might deter some students from attending lectures and create an assumption that listening to the summaries is enough to obtain all the relevant information.

  1. [1] Gardner, C., 2005. There is something in the air: podcasting in education. EDUCAUSE Review, 40(6), Nov-Dec 2005. Retrieved on May 11, 2023, from http://www.educause.edu/ir/library/pdf/erm0561.pdf
  2. [2] Berry R (2016) Podcasting: Considering the evolution of the medium and its association with the word ‘radio’. Radio Journal: International Studies in Broadcast & Audio Media 14(1): 7–22.

Questions for discussion

How can you apply podcasting in your respective courses?
